   AF, cocaine-induced MI in the past who p/w acute
   SOB, with resultant respiratory failure who has had persistent
   respiratory failure and chronic fever.
   # Fever: Patient had low-grade fevers.  Started Zosyn for G+ cocci in
   sputum and fevers in spite of current antibiotic coverage with PO vanco
   and IV Flagyl for CDiff and IV vanc for Coagulase negative Staph
   bacteremia.  For his sinusitis per CT, we had been treating with
   augmentin PO but will d/c this b/c of adequate coverage with unasyn.
   To note, prior CT abdomen [**10-18**] showed diverticulosis but no
   diverticulitis, gall bladder and pancreas were unremarkable.  Patient
   has new lines, decreasing risk of line infections.
   - follow blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Continue vancomycin IV (Day 7)  for bacteremia, switch dose to 1g q
   24hours, checking vanco trough tonight at 6 PM before next dose.
   - Continue IV Flagyl (Day 13), PO vancomycin (Day 13) for C. diff
   - d/c Augmentin (at Day 5) for sinusitis
 re-start if unasyn is d/c
   before 10 day course is not complete.
   - Tylenol PRN
   - no vegetations seen on TTE but study is poor
 may consider TEE if
   has multiple other blood cultures positive
   #Respiratory failure:  [**1-14**] CHF, fluid overload, morbid obesity.
   Patient loses volume with weaning trials, drops sat when PEEP weaned.
   Patient with mild pulmonary hyper tension, but no AS, AR, decreased
   LVEF to contribute to difficulty in weaning vent, persistent pleural
   effusions/pulmonary edema. Believe that pt is not yet eligible for
   tracheostomy due to high PEEP and risk associated with accompanying G
   tube placement.   Will sit patient upright in order to increase
   compliance and decrease PEEP, as patient may have negative end pleural
   pressures.
   - Discuss with Dr [**Last Name (STitle) 4834**] possibility of trach even with high PEEP
   requirement: what would be the upper limit of pressure support safe on
   trach?
   - Transition from  bed to chair
   -  Wean fentanyl and midazolam as tolerated
   - Difficulty diuresing b/c of increasing creatinine. Will diurese 1L as
   tolerated.
   - Continue Ipratroprium/Albuterol for possible bronchospastic component
   - PM lytes, follow creatinine.
   # Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline, but likely approximately
   1.2.  Was stable on admission, then worsened to 2.3.  Renal failure
   improved when diuresis was held.  Has had similar episode over past 3
   days.   Urine lytes and calculated FE urea again suggest pre-renal
   etiology.  Creatinine had been near baseline at 1.4, now 2.1
   -          Follow PM lytes.
   -          Hold diuretics
   # Normocytic Anemia:  Chronic issue. Per labs, unclear, probably iron
   deficiency+ anemia chronic disease.  Had bleeding episode, cauterized
   by ENT. Hct stable.
   -          Continue to monitor HCT and bleeding.
   # DM: ISS. Blood glucose stable.
   #Proptosis- Normal-high TSH, not c/w [**Doctor Last Name 598**].  Ddx includes infections
   (bacterial sinusitis, fungal invasion), infiltrative, neoplastic
   (lymphoma, leukemia).  CT imaging reassuring, with excess retro-orbital
   fat rather than lytic lesions or masses suspicious for tumor.  Per
   family is a long-standing issue.
   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin
   screen.  ACE allergic, so no ACE.  Pt has diastolic dysfunction with EF
   60-70%, so may not benefit from afterload reduction.  Though he has
   room to increase beta blockade, given infection, will hold off on
   increasing beta blockade.  ECHO showed mild pulmonary hypertension and
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   - Tolerating labetalol
   - Cont. to hold on [**Last Name (un) 239**] until patient more euvolemic
   # Atrial fibrillation: On Metoprolol and coumadin as an outpatient.
   Not anticoagulated [**1-14**] bleeding and Hct drop in hospital. CHADS score
   is 2 (CHF, DM).
   - consider re-starting anti-coagulation as nosebleeds are resolved
   - Labetolol for nonspecific receptor control
   .
   # HTN: Currently normotensive.  Initially hypertensive then
   hypotensive.
   - Continue diuresis as able
   - labetalol as above
   .
   # Gout: Stable, continue Allopurinol
   .
   # Morbid Obesity: Likely contributing to overall hypoventilation
   syndrome.  This is a chronic outpatient issue.
   - Nutrition consult post-extubation
   .
   FEN: Hypervolemic extravascularly, continue diuresis as able; replete
   PRN, DM TF while intubated.
   PPX: Heparin SQ, H2 blocker, bowel regimen.
   Access: PIVs, A-line replaced [**10-26**], New central line placed on [**10-24**]
   CODE: FULL
   .
   #Contacts:  [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6185**]

The patient has been treated with various antibiotics for suspected infections, including G+ cocci in sputum and fevers. He also has a history of diverticulosis, but no diverticulitis, and his gall bladder and pancreas are unremarkable.

The patient's physical examination reveals mild crackles bilaterally, decreased distention of the abdomen, and 2+ edema in the extremities. Neurologic examination shows sedation and response to painful stimuli.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a prolonged course of persistent ventilatory failure and a hospital course complicated by respiratory failure. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure and has developed ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The patient's condition has not improved despite receiving appropriate antibiotics for VAP. The patient also has a history of obesity, which makes it difficult to maintain adequate oxygenation with decreased levels of PEEP. 

The patient's vital signs show tachypnea, fever, and low blood pressure. The patient's heart rhythm is atrial fibrillation. The patient's lab results indicate elevated levels of white blood cells, creatinine, and lactic acid. The patient's electrolytes show hypokalemia (low potassium) and hypernatremia (high sodium). 

The patient's fluid balance shows a positive fluid balance of 3,408 mL since midnight. The patient's respiratory support includes an endotracheal tube with CPAP/PSV ventilation mode, a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 50%, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 13 cmH2O, peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 24 cmH2O, and a respiratory system compliance (RSBI) deferred due to PEEP > 10. 

The patient's physical examination reveals dullness to percussion and diminished breath sounds on the chest, as well as 2+ edema in the extremities

   Assessment and Plan
   A/P: This is a morbidly obese 53-year-old man with DMII, hypertension,
   AF, cocaine-induced MI in the past who p/w acute
   SOB, with resultant respiratory failure who has had persistent
   respiratory failure and chronic fever.
   #Respiratory failure:  [**1-14**] CHF, fluid overload, morbid obesity.
   Patient loses volume with weaning trials, drops sat when PEEP weaned.
   Patient with mild pulmonary hyper tension, but no AS, AR, decreased
   LVEF to contribute to difficulty in weaning vent, persistent pleural
   effusions/pulmonary edema. Believe that pt is not yet eligible for
   tracheostomy due to high PEEP and risk associated with accompanying G
   tube placement.   Will sit patient upright in order to increase
   compliance and decrease PEEP, as patient may have negative end pleural
   pressures.
   - Trach and PEG today with thoracics
   - Transition from  bed to chair
   -  Wean fentanyl and midazolam as tolerated
   - Difficulty diuresing b/c of increasing creatinine. Will diurese 1L as
   tolerated.
   - Continue Ipratroprium/Albuterol for possible bronchospastic component
   - PM lytes, follow creatinine.
   # Fever: Patient had low-grade fevers.  Started Zosyn for G+ cocci in
   sputum and fevers in spite of current antibiotic coverage with PO vanco
   and IV Flagyl for CDiff and IV vanc for Coagulase negative Staph
   bacteremia.  For his sinusitis per CT, we had been treating with
   augmentin PO but will d/c this b/c of adequate coverage with unasyn.
   To note, prior CT abdomen [**10-18**] showed diverticulosis but no
   diverticulitis, gall bladder and pancreas were unremarkable.  Patient
   has new lines, decreasing risk of line infections.
   - follow blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Continue vancomycin IV (Day 8)  for bacteremia, switch dose to 1g q
   24hours, checking vanco trough
   - Continue IV Flagyl (Day 14), PO vancomycin (Day 14) for C. diff
   - Tylenol PRN
   - no vegetations seen on TTE but study is poor
 may consider TEE if
   has multiple other blood cultures positive
   # Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline, but likely approximately
   1.2.  Was stable on admission, then worsened to 2.3.  Renal failure
   improved when diuresis was held.  Has had similar episode over past 3
   days.   Urine lytes and calculated FE urea again suggest pre-renal
   etiology.  Creatinine had gone up to 2.1, now back down to 1.8
   -          Follow PM lytes.
   -      D/c Lasix drip.  Bolus Lasix 80 mg IV x 1 this AM, recheck in PM
   for creatinine rise
   # DM: ISS. Elevated blood sugars.
   -Increase fixed Lantus dose.
   # Normocytic Anemia:  Chronic issue. Per labs, unclear, probably iron
   deficiency+ anemia chronic disease.  Had bleeding episode, cauterized
   by ENT. Hct stable.
   -          Continue to monitor HCT and bleeding.
   #Proptosis- Normal-high TSH, not c/w [**Doctor Last Name 598**].  Ddx includes infections
   (bacterial sinusitis, fungal invasion), infiltrative, neoplastic
   (lymphoma, leukemia).  CT imaging reassuring, with excess retro-orbital
   fat rather than lytic lesions or masses suspicious for tumor.  Per
   family is a long-standing issue.
   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin
   screen.  ACE allergic, so no ACE.  Pt has diastolic dysfunction with EF
   60-70%, so may not benefit from afterload reduction.  Though he has
   room to increase beta blockade, given infection, will hold off on
   increasing beta blockade.  ECHO showed mild pulmonary hypertension and
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   - Tolerating labetalol
   - Cont. to hold on [**Last Name (un) 239**] until patient more euvolemic
   # Atrial fibrillation: On Metoprolol and coumadin as an outpatient.
   Not anticoagulated [**1-14**] bleeding and Hct drop in hospital. CHADS score
   is 2 (CHF, DM).
   - hold on anticoagulation given potential trach in next few days.
   - Labetolol for nonspecific receptor control
   .
   # HTN: Currently normotensive.  Initially hypertensive then
   hypotensive.
   - Continue diuresis as able
   - labetalol as above
   .
   # Gout: Stable, continue Allopurinol
   .
   # Morbid Obesity: Likely contributing to overall hypoventilation
   syndrome.  This is a chronic outpatient issue.
   - Nutrition consult post-extubation
   .
   FEN: Hypervolemic extravascularly, continue diuresis as able; replete
   PRN, DM TF while intubated.
   PPX: Heparin SQ, H2 blocker, bowel regimen.
   Access: PIVs, A-line replaced [**10-26**], New central line placed on [**10-24**]
   CODE: FULL

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old man with multiple medical conditions including diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He was admitted with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure. The patient has been in the ICU for several days and has developed various complications.

Potential medical complications that can arise in this case include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient initially presented with respiratory failure due to acute shortness of breath. He has been on mechanical ventilation and is currently on CPAP/PSV mode. The respiratory support is necessary due to his underlying morbid obesity, chronic fever, pulmonary hypertension, and persistent pleural effusions/pulmonary edema.

2. Fever: The patient has had persistent low-grade fevers, which indicate an ongoing infection. He has been treated with antibiotics for gram-positive cocci in the sputum and fevers. There is a concern for hospital-acquired pneumonia or ventilator-associated pneumonia.

3. Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function has been fluctuating, with an initial creatinine level of approximately 1.2, which worsened to 2.3 and then improved. This suggests pre-renal etiology. The patient may require careful monitoring of fluid balance and renal function.

4. Diabetic issues: The patient has elevated blood sugars, indicating uncontrolled diabetes. His insulin dose needs to be adjusted accordingly.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 53-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath and subsequent respiratory failure. The patient has had persistent respiratory failure, chronic fever, and multiple infections. He also has chronic issues with normocytic anemia, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, gout, and morbid obesity.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient has experienced persistent respiratory failure due to factors such as chronic fever, infections, and morbid obesity.

2. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has worsened from approximately 1.2 to 2.3, indicating acute renal failure. This could be due to pre-renal causes, and the patient's fluid status, blood pressure, and creatinine levels need to be closely monitored.

3. Diabetic Mellitus: The patient has elevated blood sugars, indicating uncontrolled diabetes. Insulin therapy needs to be managed carefully, especially during periods of NPO (nothing by mouth).

4. Coagulopathy: The patient has had episodes of coagulation issues, including bacteremia and positive stool toxin for Clostridium difficile infection. Close monitoring of coagulation parameters is necessary.

5. Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: The patient has a history of myocardial infarction

   effusions/pulmonary edema. Pt tolerated sitting trial well, with good
   tidal volumes and O2 saturation.

   secretions and fever.  [**Month (only) 60**] have had GNRs deep in lungs that did not
   appear on sputum.  G+ cocci in sputum should be covered with
   Vancomycin.
   ii.  Coag negative staph bacteremia- IV vancomycin, day 8.  Last vanco

   iii.  Sinusitis- d/c
d Unasyn.  Most organisms should be covered with

   # Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline, but likely approximately

   -half-dose glargine today, given that patient is having tube feeds held

   # Normocytic Anemia:  Chronic issue. Per labs, unclear, probably iron
   deficiency+ anemia chronic disease.  Had bleeding episode, cauterized

   -          Continue to monitor HCT and bleeding.
   #Proptosis- Normal-high TSH, not c/w [**Doctor Last Name 598**].  Ddx includes infections

   (lymphoma, leukemia).  CT imaging reassuring, with excess retro-orbital

   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction in the past. The patient presented with acute shortness of breath and subsequently developed respiratory failure.

The patient has had persistent respiratory failure and chronic fever. The possible causes for respiratory failure include CHF, fluid overload, and morbid obesity. The patient has also shown signs of mild pulmonary hypertension but no aortic or mitral stenosis, decreased left ventricular ejection fraction contributing to difficulty in weaning off the ventilator, and persistent pleural effusions/pulmonary edema.

The patient has been diagnosed with various conditions such as ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia, sinusitis, and Clostridium difficile infection. Treatment plans have been initiated for these conditions, including the administration of appropriate antibiotics and supportive care.

Additionally, the patient has acute renal failure with fluctuating renal insufficiency, possibly due to pre-renal causes. The patient's blood sugars have been elevated, indicating uncontrolled diabetes mellitus.

The patient also has normocytic anemia, which is a chronic issue. There is a suspicion of an underlying cause such as iron deficiency anemia or chronic disease. The patient's proptosis is stable, and imaging studies do not show any lytic lesions or

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a significant history of obesity, persistent respiratory failure, and the need for tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) to allow for long-term ventilator wean and support. The patient has been tolerating pressure support ventilation (PSV) wean and PEEP decrease to 12. There is no evidence of significant new positive cultures.

Assessment and Plan:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient may have pneumonia contributing to respiratory failure, along with volume overload and obesity. Diuresis and mobilization will continue to facilitate wean of ventilatory support.
2. Sepsis: The patient has multiple active sources of ICU-related infections, which appear to be reasonably controlled. These include catheter-related bloodstream infection, ventilator-associated pneumonia, and Clostridium difficile infection. Antibiotic therapy will be continued.
3. Altered Mental Status: Sedation wean will continue as tolerated, and daily wake-ups with airway stabilization will be implemented.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's underlying respiratory failure may worsen due to pneumonia, volume overload, and obesity. Weaning off the ventilator and managing respiratory support will be crucial.
2. Sepsis: The patient's multiple active sources of ICU-related infections increase the risk of sepsis. Continued antibiotic therapy and infection control measures are essential.
3. Altered Mental Status: Weaning off

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath and subsequent respiratory failure, which has persisted along with chronic fever.

The patient's current medical issues include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient is experiencing difficulty weaning from the ventilator, with decreased tidal volumes and oxygen saturation when PEEP is weaned. There are mild pulmonary hypertension and persistent pleural effusions/pulmonary edema. The patient is planned for tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) today.

2. Fever: The patient has had multiple infections, low-grade fevers, but has been afebrile for two days since starting Zosyn empiric coverage for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). The VAP is suspected due to increasing secretions and fever.

3. Coag-negative staph bacteremia: The patient had positive blood cultures for coag-negative staph bacteremia, which was treated with intravenous vancomycin. The dose of vancomycin was held due to decreased renal function.

4. C. difficile infection: The patient has a positive stool toxin for Clostridium difficile infection, being treated with intravenous Flagyl and oral vancomycin.

5. Acute renal failure: The patient's baseline renal function

   Assessment and Plan
   A/P: This is a morbidly obese 53-year-old man with DMII, hypertension,
   AF, cocaine-induced MI in the past who p/w acute
   SOB, with resultant respiratory failure who has had persistent
   respiratory failure and chronic fever.
   #Respiratory failure:  [**1-14**] CHF, fluid overload, morbid obesity.
   Patient loses volume with weaning trials, drops sat when PEEP weaned.
   Patient with mild pulmonary hyper tension, but no AS, AR, decreased
   LVEF to contribute to difficulty in weaning vent, persistent pleural
   effusions/pulmonary edema. Pt tolerated sitting trial well, with good
   tidal volumes and O2 saturation.
   - Trach and PEG today with thoracics
   - Transition from  bed to chair
   -  Wean fentanyl and midazolam as tolerated
   - Hold diuresis until post-procedure, to avoid hypotension and
   peri-operative excess fluid resuscitation.
   - Continue Ipratroprium/Albuterol for possible bronchospastic component
   - PM lytes, follow creatinine.
   # Fever: Patient has had multiple infections, low-grade fevers, but has
   been afebrile x 2 days since Zosyn was started over the weekend.
   i.  VAP- Started Zosyn empiric coverage of VAP, given increasing
   secretions and fever.  [**Month (only) 60**] have had GNRs deep in lungs that did not
   appear on sputum.  G+ cocci in sputum should be covered with
   Vancomycin.
   ii.  Coag negative staph bacteremia- IV vancomycin, day 8.  Last vanco
   trough was therapeutic after dose was held [**1-14**] decreased renal function
   iii.  Sinusitis- d/c
d Unasyn.  Most organisms should be covered with
   Vanco and Zosyn
   iv.  C. diff- Positive stool toxin.  Being treated with IV Flagyl (day
   14), PO vanco
   - Continue blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Continue vancomycin IV (Day 8)  for bacteremia, switch dose to 1g q
   24hours,
   - ID approval per Zosyn
   - Continue IV Flagyl (Day 14), PO vancomycin (Day 14) for C. diff
   - Tylenol PRN
   - no vegetations seen on TTE but study is poor
 may consider TEE if
   has multiple other blood cultures positive
   # Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline, but likely approximately
   1.2.  Was stable on admission, then worsened to 2.3.  Fluctuating renal
   insufficiency likely [**1-14**] pre-renal causes.  Now back down to 1.8.
   Patient did well on Lasix boluses.
   -          Follow PM lytes.
   -          Hold lasix boluses until after the procedure.  Resume
   depending on fluid status, BP, and creatinine.
   # DM: ISS. Elevated blood sugars.
   -half-dose glargine today, given that patient is having tube feeds held
   and had been getting insulin sliding scale.
   # Normocytic Anemia:  Chronic issue. Per labs, unclear, probably iron
   deficiency+ anemia chronic disease.  Had bleeding episode, cauterized
   by ENT. Hct stable.
   -          Continue to monitor HCT and bleeding.
   #Proptosis- Normal-high TSH, not c/w [**Doctor Last Name 598**].  Ddx includes infections
   (bacterial sinusitis, fungal invasion), infiltrative, neoplastic
   (lymphoma, leukemia).  CT imaging reassuring, with excess retro-orbital
   fat rather than lytic lesions or masses suspicious for tumor.  Per
   family is a long-standing issue.
   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin
   screen.  ACE allergic, so no ACE.  Pt has diastolic dysfunction with EF
   60-70%, so may not benefit from afterload reduction.  Though he has
   room to increase beta blockade, given infection, will hold off on
   increasing beta blockade.  ECHO showed mild pulmonary hypertension and
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   - Tolerating labetalol
   - Cont. to hold on [**Last Name (un) 239**] until patient more euvolemic
   # Atrial fibrillation: On Metoprolol and coumadin as an outpatient.
   Not anticoagulated [**1-14**] bleeding and Hct drop in hospital. CHADS score
   is 2 (CHF, DM).
   - hold on anticoagulation given potential trach in next few days.
   - Labetolol for nonspecific receptor control
   .
   # HTN: Currently normotensive.  Initially hypertensive then
   hypotensive.
   - Continue diuresis as able
   - labetalol as above
   .
   # Gout: Stable, continue Allopurinol
   .
   # Morbid Obesity: Likely contributing to overall hypoventilation
   syndrome.  This is a chronic outpatient issue.
   - Nutrition consult post-extubation
   .
   FEN: Hypervolemic extravascularly, continue diuresis as able; replete
   PRN, DM TF while intubated.
   PPX: Heparin SQ, H2 blocker, bowel regimen.
   Access: PIVs, A-line replaced [**10-26**], New central line placed on [**10-24**]
   Dispo: begin screening for rehab facilities.
   CODE: FULL
   #Contacts:  [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6185**]

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath, resulting in respiratory failure. The patient has had persistent respiratory failure and chronic fever. He has been intubated and on mechanical ventilation. The patient's current medications include fentanyl, midazolam, haloperidol, and various antibiotics.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient has persistent respiratory failure despite being on mechanical ventilation. The main contributing factors include morbid obesity, chronic fluid overload, congestive heart failure, and pulmonary hypertension.
2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation for an extended period and has developed a fever, suggesting a possible infection. Empiric coverage for VAP has been started with piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn).
3. Coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia: The patient developed bacteremia caused by coagulase-negative staphylococci. Vancomycin therapy was initiated and continued due to persistent bacteremia.
4. Clostridium difficile infection: The patient tested positive for C. difficile toxin, indicating a possible infection. Treatment with oral vancomycin and metronidazole has been initiated.
5. Acute renal failure: The patient

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 70-year-old male admitted to the ICU with multiple medical complications. He has a history of diabetes mellitus type II, obesity, atrial fibrillation, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction, chronic respiratory failure, renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, and impaired skin integrity. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU and is being treated for fever of unknown origin, electrolyte imbalances, and gastrointestinal issues.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is on mechanical ventilation, which increases the risk of developing VAP. Close monitoring of respiratory parameters and daily evaluation of secretions should be done to prevent and detect early signs of VAP.
2. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): Prolonged immobility in the ICU increases the risk of DVT. Prophylactic measures such as compression stockings, early ambulation, and subcutaneous heparin may be necessary to prevent DVT.
3. Stress ulcer: Critical illness and mechanical ventilation can lead to stress-related mucosal damage, resulting in stress ulcers. Proton pump inhibitors or histamine-2 receptor antagonists may be prescribed for stress ulcer prophylaxis.
4. Renal failure: The patient has pre-existing renal failure, and the use of nephrotoxic medications or ongoing renal dysfunction may worsen renal function. Close monitoring of renal parameters and careful management of fluid and electrolyte balance is essential.

The patient also has chronic fever, and multiple infections have been identified, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), coag-negative staph bacteremia, and Clostridium difficile infection. He has acute renal failure with fluctuating renal insufficiency, likely due to pre-renal causes. The patient's prothosis is normal to high, and further evaluation is needed to determine the underlying cause. He has ischemic cardiomyopathy with a reduced ejection fraction of 60-70%. The patient is currently agitated and not following commands, likely due to language barriers.

- The patient's renal function has fluctuated, but is currently stable.
- He is being closely monitored for potential complications and is receiving appropriate treatments for his various conditions.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old male with a chief complaint of respiratory failure. The patient has been in the ICU and has undergone several procedures, including the placement of a tracheostomy tube and G-tube. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 38.3°C, heart rate of 87 bpm, blood pressure of 113/66 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95%. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with a mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, set tidal volume of 400 mL, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, PEEP of 18 cmH2O, FiO2 of 50%, and SpO2 of 95%. The patient's ABG results show a pH of 7.42, PaCO2 of 57 mmHg, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 144, and HCO3- of 72 mEq/L.

The patient's physical examination reveals dullness on percussion and decreased breath sounds over the right lower lobe. Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 339 K/uL, elevated blood urea nitrogen (BUN) of 149 mg/dL, elevated creatinine (Cr) of 1.7 mg/dL, and electrolyte imbalances including hypokalemia (low potassium) and hypernatremia (high sodium). The patient also has an elevated lactate level of 0.7 mmol/L. Imaging shows severe worsening of the right lower lobe atelectasis and collapse.

The patient's assessment and plan include respiratory failure due to persistent ventilatory failure and volume overload, as well as renal failure. The patient's respiratory support is being weaned gradually, and bronchoscopy may be performed if recruitment of the right lower lobe is not achieved. The patient also has a fever, likely secondary to peri-procedure aspiration and atelectasis. Antibiotics have been started, and culture results are pending. The patient's acute renal failure is being managed with careful fluid balance and electrolyte monitoring.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), further deterioration of renal function, and electrolyte imbalances.

   Assessment and Plan
   A/P: This is a morbidly obese 53-year-old man with DMII, hypertension,
   AF, cocaine-induced MI in the past who p/w acute
   SOB, with resultant respiratory failure who has had persistent
   respiratory failure and chronic fever.
   #1 Respiratory failure:  [**1-14**] CHF, fluid overload, morbid obesity,
   aspiration pneumonia.  Patient loses volume with weaning trials, drops
   sat when PEEP weaned.  Patient with mild pulmonary hyper tension, but
   no AS, AR, decreased LVEF to contribute to difficulty in weaning vent,
   persistent pleural effusions/pulmonary edema. Pt tolerated sitting
   trial well, with good tidal volumes and O2 saturation.  Failed several
   attempts to ween PEEP, patient now w/tracheostomy and since procedure
   is back on CMV/Assist.  Received diuresis and recruit maneuvers with
   brief post-op episode of desaturation and sats improved.
   - CMV -> PSV at 10/18 as tolerated, re-check ABG in afternoon
   - Wean fentanyl and midazolam as tolerated
   - Diuresis as tolerated
   - Continue Ipratroprium/Albuterol for possible bronchospastic component
   - PM lytes, follow creatinine.
   #2  Fever: Patient has had multiple infections, low-grade fevers, but
   had been afebrile x 2 days since Zosyn was started.  Now low grade temp
   x2 days, temp to 101.4 overnight..  BCx and UCx sent, due to height of
   fever and persistence, it is unlikely that it is due to stress from the
   procedure yesterday.
   I    VAP- Started Zosyn on [**10-28**] for empiric coverage of VAP, given
   increasing secretions and fever.  [**Month (only) 60**] have had GNRs deep in lungs that
   did not appear on sputum.  Defervesed with addition of zosyn.  Now day
   6.  Re-assess endpoint when Cx from [**11-2**] are resulted.
   ii.  Coag negative staph bacteremia- IV vancomycin, started [**10-24**], now
   day 10.  Re-assess endpoint when Cx from [**11-2**] are resulted.
   iii.  Sinusitis- d/c
d Unasyn, ammoxicillin.  Most organisms should be
   covered with Vanco and Zosyn
   iv.  C. diff- Positive stool toxin.  Being treated with IV Flagyl (day
   14), PO vanco until 2 weeks after antibiotics d/c.
   - Continue to follow blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Continue vancomycin IV (Day 10)  for bacteremia, switched dose to 1g
   q 24hours,
   - Continue IV Flagyl (Day 16), PO vancomycin (Day 16) for C. diff
   - Tylenol PRN
   - no vegetations seen on TTE but study is poor
 may consider TEE if
   has multiple other blood cultures positive
   #3 Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline, but likely approximately
   1.2.  Was stable on admission, then worsened to 2.3.  Fluctuating renal
   insufficiency likely [**1-14**] pre-renal causes.  Now 1.7.  Patient did well
   with Lasix boluses.
   -          Continue to follow PM lytes.
   -          Lasix bolus as tolerated
   # DM: ISS.
   # Normocytic Anemia:  Chronic issue. Per labs, unclear, probably iron
   deficiency+ anemia chronic disease.  Had bleeding episode, cauterized
   by ENT. Hct stable.
   -          Continue to monitor HCT and bleeding.
   #Proptosis- Normal-high TSH, not c/w [**Doctor Last Name 598**].  Ddx includes infections
   (bacterial sinusitis, fungal invasion), infiltrative, neoplastic
   (lymphoma, leukemia).  CT imaging reassuring, with excess retro-orbital
   fat rather than lytic lesions or masses suspicious for tumor.  Per
   family is a long-standing issue.
   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin
   screen.  ACE allergic, so no ACE.  Pt has diastolic dysfunction with EF
   60-70%, so may not benefit from afterload reduction.  Though he has
   room to increase beta blockade, given infection, will hold off on
   increasing beta blockade.  ECHO showed mild pulmonary hypertension and
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   - Tolerating labetalol
   - Cont. to hold on [**Last Name (un) 239**] until patient more euvolemic
   # Atrial fibrillation: On Metoprolol and coumadin as an outpatient.
   Not anticoagulated [**1-14**] bleeding and Hct drop in hospital. CHADS score
   is 2 (CHF, DM).
   - Heparin gtt and re-assess for anticoagulation.
   - Labetolol for rate control
   .
   # HTN: Currently normotensive.  Initially hypertensive then
   hypotensive.
   - Continue diuresis as able
   - labetalol as above
   .
   # Gout: Stable, continue Allopurinol
   .
   # Morbid Obesity: Likely contributing to overall hypoventilation
   syndrome.  This is a chronic outpatient issue.
   - Nutrition consult post-extubation
   .
   FEN: Hypervolemic extravascularly, continue diuresis as able; replete
   PRN, DM TF until patient cleared by speech/swallow.
   PPX: Heparin SQ, H2 blocker, bowel regimen.
   Access: PICC placed by IR.
   Dispo: begin screening for rehab facilities.
   CODE: FULL

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old man with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure, which has persisted despite various interventions. He has had chronic fever, and multiple cultures have shown no growth, except for coag-negative staph bacteremia that is currently being treated with vancomycin. The patient also has a positive stool toxin for Clostridium difficile infection and is being treated with IV Flagyl and PO vancomycin. He has acute renal failure, normocytic anemia, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, gout, and morbid obesity. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory failure persists despite being on mechanical ventilation. There are concerns about weaning off the ventilator due to difficulty maintaining oxygen saturation and dealing with pleural effusions/pulmonary edema.
2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed a fever, and there is a concern for VAP. Empiric coverage with Zosyn has been started, and cultures are pending.
3. Coag-Negative Staph Bacteremia: The patient has a history of bacteremia with coag-negative staph, which is currently being treated with vancomycin.
4. Clostridium difficile

   SOB, with resultant respiratory failure who has had persistent
   respiratory failure and chronic fever.
   #1 Respiratory failure:  [**1-14**] CHF, fluid overload, morbid obesity,
   aspiration pneumonia.  Patient loses volume with weaning trials, drops
   sat when PEEP weaned.  Patient with mild pulmonary hyper tension, but
   no AS, AR, decreased LVEF to contribute to difficulty in weaning vent,
   persistent pleural effusions/pulmonary edema. Pt tolerated sitting
   trial well, with good tidal volumes and O2 saturation.  Failed several
   attempts to ween PEEP, patient now w/tracheostomy and since procedure
   is back on CMV/Assist.  Received diuresis and recruit maneuvers with
   brief post-op episode of desaturation and sats improved.
   - CMV -> PSV at 10/18 as tolerated, re-check ABG in afternoon
   - Wean fentanyl and midazolam as tolerated
   - Diuresis as tolerated
   - Continue Ipratroprium/Albuterol for possible bronchospastic component
   - PM lytes, follow creatinine.
   #2  Fever: Patient has had multiple infections, low-grade fevers, but
   had been afebrile x 2 days since Zosyn was started.  Now w/low grade
   temp since yesterday afternoon.  BCx and UCx sent but its possible that
   fever is due to stress from procedure yesterday.
   i.  VAP- Started Zosyn empiric coverage of VAP, given increasing
   secretions and fever.  [**Month (only) 60**] have had GNRs deep in lungs that did not
   appear on sputum.  G+ cocci in sputum should be covered with

   iii.  Sinusitis- d/c

 may consider TEE if

The patient is a 53-year-old male with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presents with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure, which has been persistent. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 101.4°F, blood pressure ranging from 120/69 to 148/87 mmHg, heart rate between 69-95 bpm, respiratory rate between 13-27 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 95%.

The patient is currently intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in the ICU. His current medications include vancomycin, piperacillin/tazobactam (Zosyn), metronidazole, fentanyl, midazolam, and lasix. The patient has been diagnosed with various conditions including respiratory failure, chronic fever, acute renal failure, diabetes mellitus, normocytic anemia, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, gout, and morbid obesity.

The patient's lab results show elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin, elevated blood glucose levels, abnormal liver function tests, and increased creatinine levels. Imaging studies reveal excess retro-orbital fat but no lytic lesions or masses suspicious for tumor.

The patient's assessment and plan include treatment for respiratory failure, chronic fever, acute renal failure, and other comorbidities. He

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presents with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure, for which he was admitted to the ICU. The patient has had persistent respiratory failure, chronic fever, and multiple infections. He has also experienced acute renal failure, normocytic anemia, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, gout, morbid obesity, and hypernatremia.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure is likely due to chronic fever, aspiration pneumonia, CHF, fluid overload, and morbid obesity. Weaning from mechanical ventilation has been difficult, and the patient has experienced episodes of desaturation during PEEP weaning. Tracheostomy has been performed, and the patient is currently on continuous mandatory ventilation (CMV) with assist.

2. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has developed low-grade fever, increasing secretions, and worsening oxygenation, which may indicate VAP. Empiric coverage with Zosyn has been started, and blood cultures are pending.

3. Coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia: The patient had a positive blood culture for coag-negative staphylococci, and IV vancomycin has been initiated. Vancom

The patient's temperature is elevated at 101.4°F (38.6°C). The patient has a history of diabetes mellitus type II and obesity. The patient's neurologic exam is not fully assessed due to intubation. The patient's abdominal exam is soft and non-tender with bowel sounds present.    Assessment and Plan
   A/P: This is a morbidly obese 53-year-old man with DMII, hypertension,
   AF, cocaine-induced MI in the past who p/w acute
   SOB, with resultant respiratory failure who has had persistent
   respiratory failure and chronic fever.
   #1 Respiratory failure:  [**1-14**] CHF, fluid overload, morbid obesity,
   aspiration pneumonia.  Patient loses volume with weaning trials, drops
   sat when PEEP weaned.  Patient with mild pulmonary hyper tension, but
   no AS, AR, decreased LVEF to contribute to difficulty in weaning vent,
   persistent pleural effusions/pulmonary edema. Pt tolerated sitting
   trial well, with good tidal volumes and O2 saturation.  Failed several
   attempts to ween PEEP, patient now w/tracheostomy and since procedure
   is back on PSV.  Received diuresis and recruit maneuvers with brief
   post-op episode of desaturation and sats improved.
   - wean PEEP
   - Wean fentanyl and midazolam as tolerated; consider haldol if needed
   for agitation.
   - Hold diuresis today due to elevated creatinine
   - Continue Ipratroprium/Albuterol for possible bronchospastic component
   - Consider cardiology consult to advise regarding CHF contribution.
   .
   #2  Fever: Patient has had multiple infections, low-grade fevers, but
   had been afebrile x 2 days since Zosyn was started.  Now low grade temp
   x2 days, temp to 101.4 overnight..  BCx and UCx sent, due to height of
   fever and persistence, it is unlikely that it is due to stress from the
   procedure yesterday.  Has been afebrile overnight.
   I    VAP- Started Zosyn on [**10-28**] for empiric coverage of VAP, given
   increasing secretions and fever.  [**Month (only) 60**] have had GNRs deep in lungs that
   did not appear on sputum.  Defervesed with addition of zosyn.  Now day
   8.  Re-assess endpoint when Cx from [**11-2**] are resulted.
   ii.  Coag negative staph bacteremia- IV vancomycin, started [**10-24**], now
   day 11.  Re-assess endpoint when Cx from [**11-2**] are resulted.
   iii.  Sinusitis- d/c
d Unasyn, ammoxicillin.  Most organisms should be
   covered with Vanco and Zosyn
   iv.  C. diff- Positive stool toxin.  Being treated with IV Flagyl (day
   14), PO vanco until 2 weeks after antibiotics d/c.
   - Continue to follow blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Continue vancomycin IV (started [**10-24**], Day 11)  for bacteremia,
   switched dose to 1g q 24hours,
   - Continue IV Flagyl (started [**10-18**], Day 17), PO vancomycin (started
   [**10-18**] Day 17) for C. diff
   - Tylenol PRN
   - no vegetations seen on TTE but study is poor
 may consider TEE if
   has multiple other blood cultures positive
   #3 Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline; 1.2 on admission but has
   been in the 1.6
 2.0 range for the past year.  Was stable on
   admission, then worsened to 2.3.  Fluctuating renal insufficiency
   likely [**1-14**] pre-renal causes.  Now 1.8.  Patient did well with Lasix
   boluses.
   -          Continue to follow PM lytes.
   -          Lasix bolus as tolerated
   # DM: ISS with standing glargine
   # Normocytic Anemia:  Chronic issue. Per labs, unclear, probably iron
   deficiency+ anemia chronic disease.  Had bleeding episode, cauterized
   by ENT. Hct stable.
   -          Continue to monitor HCT and bleeding.
   #Proptosis- Normal-high TSH, not c/w [**Doctor Last Name 598**].  Ddx includes infections
   (bacterial sinusitis, fungal invasion), infiltrative, neoplastic
   (lymphoma, leukemia).  CT imaging reassuring, with excess retro-orbital
   fat rather than lytic lesions or masses suspicious for tumor.  Per
   family is a long-standing issue.
   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin
   screen.  ACE allergic, so no ACE.  Pt has diastolic dysfunction with EF
   60-70%, so may not benefit from afterload reduction.  Though he has
   room to increase beta blockade, given infection, will hold off on
   increasing beta blockade.  ECHO showed mild pulmonary hypertension and
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   - Tolerating labetalol
   - Cont. to hold on [**Last Name (un) 239**] until patient more euvolemic
   # Atrial fibrillation: On Metoprolol and coumadin as an outpatient.
   Not anticoagulated [**1-14**] bleeding and Hct drop in hospital. CHADS score
   is 2 (CHF, DM).
   - Heparin gtt and re-assess for anticoagulation.
   - Labetolol for rate control
   .
   # HTN: Currently normotensive.  Initially hypertensive then
   hypotensive.
   - Continue diuresis as able
   - labetalol as above
   .
   # Gout: Stable, continue Allopurinol
   .
   # Morbid Obesity: Likely contributing to overall hypoventilation
   syndrome.  This is a chronic outpatient issue.
   - Nutrition consult post-extubation
   .
   FEN: Hypervolemic extravascularly, continue diuresis as able; replete
   PRN, DM TF until patient cleared by speech/swallow; consider
   post-pyloric tube placement by IR.
   PPX: Heparin gtt, H2 blocker, bowel regimen.
   Access: PICC placed by IR.
   Dispo: begin screening for rehab facilities.
   CODE: FULL
   #Contacts:  [**Telephone/Fax (1) 6185**]

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese male with diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presents with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure, leading to chronic fever. He has been in the ICU for several days, requiring mechanical ventilation and tracheostomy. The patient's medical conditions include respiratory failure, fever, coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia, sinusitis, Clostridium difficile infection, acute renal failure, normocytic anemia, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory function remains compromised, with difficulty weaning off the ventilator and persistent pulmonary hypertension.
2. Infection: The patient has had multiple infections, including VAP, bacteremia, sinusitis, and C. difficile infection. He continues to be at risk for further infections due to prolonged ICU stay and immunosuppression.
3. Acute renal failure: The patient's renal function has fluctuated, with elevated creatinine levels. He requires close monitoring of renal parameters and careful management of fluid balance.
4. Normocytic anemia: The patient has chronic anemia, which may contribute to his overall weakness and fatigue.
5. Proptosis: The patient has proptosis, which requires further evaluation to determine the underlying

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure. The patient has been in the ICU for several days, experiencing persistent respiratory failure, chronic fever, and multiple infections. He has been treated with various antibiotics, including vancomycin and Zosyn, for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), coag-negative staph bacteremia, sinusitis, and Clostridium difficile infection. The patient's renal function has fluctuated, and he has been given lasix boluses. His proptosis is due to excess retro-orbital fat and not caused by infection or tumor. The patient has ischemic cardiomyopathy with prior myocardial infarction and cocaine use, mild pulmonary hypertension, and tricuspid regurgitation. He has been on metoprolol and coumadin for atrial fibrillation but was not anticoagulated due to bleeding and Hct drop. The patient's blood pressure has been unstable, initially hypertensive then hypotensive. He has a history of gout, morbid obesity contributing to hypoventilation syndrome, and normocytic anemia. The patient's code status is full code, and he is being screened for rehabilitation facilities.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 53-year-old man with diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction.
- He presented with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure.
- The patient has been in the ICU for an extended period, with persistent respiratory failure and chronic fever.
- He has multiple comorbidities including congestive heart failure, fluid overload, morbid obesity, and aspiration pneumonia.
- The patient has had difficulty weaning off mechanical ventilation due to pulmonary hypertension, but tolerated a sitting trial well.
- He has undergone several interventions including tracheostomy, diuresis, recruitment maneuvers, and antibiotic therapy.
- The patient's recent labs show elevated creatinine levels, leading to holding diuretics.
- His fever has recurred, and blood cultures have shown coag-negative staph bacteremia, which is being treated with vancomycin.
- The patient also has sinusitis, C. difficile infection, and acute renal failure.
- Other ongoing issues include diabetes mellitus, normocytic anemia, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, hypertension, gout, and morbid obesity.
- The patient is currently receiving various medications, including labetalol for rate control in atrial fibrillation, allopurinol for gout, and antibiotics for infections.
- His current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 92 bpm, blood pressure of 126/74 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure and difficulty weaning off mechanical ventilation indicate a high risk for continued respiratory failure.
2. Infection: The patient has recurrent fevers, positive blood cultures indicating coag-negative staph bacteremia and C. difficile infection, suggesting an ongoing risk for infections.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's fluctuating renal insufficiency and elevated creatinine levels indicate a risk for worsening renal function.
4. Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: The patient's history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction and ischemic cardiomyopathy put him at risk for further cardiac complications.
5. Atrial Fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation may lead to thromboembolic events if not adequately anticoagulated.
6. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and recent fluctuations in blood pressure suggest ongoing cardiovascular risks.
7. Morbid Obesity: The patient's morbid obesity contributes to hypoventilation syndrome and increases the risk of respiratory and cardiovascular complications.

The patient is a 53-year-old male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a past cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath, leading to respiratory failure. He has been experiencing chronic fever, and there are concerns about ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), coag-neg staph bacteremia, and sinusitis. The patient also has acute renal failure, normocytic anemia, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, gout, and hypervolemic extravascular fluid status. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Decompensation: The patient has experienced acute respiratory decompensation due to likely aspiration of blood from nosebleeds. Chronic respiratory failure from congestive heart failure (CHF), fluid overload, and obesity may also contribute. 2. Fever: The patient has been febrile for most of his stay, but was afebrile for two days after starting Zosyn. He was also febrile around peg placement. Now he is afebrile for two days. VAP was started on Zosyn on [**Month (only) 60**] for empirical coverage of VAP, given increasing secretions and fever. The patient defervesced with the addition of Zosyn. Re-assessment endpoint now has respiratory decompensation with likely aspiration of blood.

3. Coag-Neg Staph Bacteremia: IV vancomycin, started on [**10-24**], is being continued for bacteremia, covering VAP and bacteremia. 

4. Sinusitis: The patient's sinusitis has been discontinued.

5. Clostridium difficile (C. diff): The patient has a positive stool toxin, indicating C. diff. He is being treated with IV Flagyl (day 15), and PO vancomycin until two weeks after antibiotics discontinuation.

6. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's renal function has fluctuated, with unclear baseline. He had stable creatinine levels on admission, but they worsened to 2.3. Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 53-year-old man with a medical history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, cocaine-induced myocardial infarction, and morbid obesity. He was admitted with acute shortness of breath and respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing chronic fever, and multiple infections have been identified, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), coag-negative staph bacteremia, and Clostridium difficile infection. He also has acute renal failure, normocytic anemia, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, and atrial fibrillation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Respiratory Failure: The patient's obesity and chronic respiratory failure pose a risk for continued difficulty weaning from mechanical ventilation. The presence of pleural effusions and pulmonary edema may contribute to this issue.

2. Fever: The patient's persistent low-grade fever suggests an ongoing infection. Given his history of multiple infections, including VAP and bacteremia, it is important to monitor for any signs of worsening infection or sepsis.

3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's fluctuating renal function indicates acute renal failure. Pre-renal causes such as hypovolemia and hypotension should be considered, along with possible intrinsic renal damage. Close monitoring of fluid balance and renal function is essential.

4. Diabetes Mellitus Type II: The patient's diabetes should be managed with appropriate insulin therapy and blood glucose monitoring

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old man with multiple comorbidities including diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath and subsequently developed respiratory failure. The patient has been experiencing chronic fever and has positive blood cultures for gram-negative rods (GNRs) that were not present in sputum samples. The patient also has coagulase-negative staphylococcal bacteremia.

The patient's respiratory status has been unstable, with acute respiratory decompensation likely due to aspiration of blood from nosebleeds. Chronic respiratory failure may be attributed to congestive heart failure (CHF), fluid overload, and obesity. The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, set at a tidal volume of 490 mL, peak inspiratory pressure of 33 cmH2O, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%, and positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 22 cmH2O.

The patient's renal function has fluctuated, with a baseline creatinine level of 1.2 but now at 1.5. He has been receiving Lasix boluses as tolerated. The patient's diabetes mellitus is being managed with glargine insulin and a sliding scale.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese man with diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath, leading to respiratory failure. He has had persistent respiratory failure and chronic fever. The patient's current condition includes acute respiratory decompensation, likely due to aspiration of blood from nosebleeds, chronic respiratory failure from congestive heart failure (CHF), fluid overload, and obesity. He is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube, CPAP/PSV mode, PEEP of 22 cmH2O, FiO2 of 60%, and has an ABG showing a pH of 7.39, PaCO2 of 59 mmHg, PaO2 of 175, and HCO3- of 38 mEq/L. His vital signs include a heart rate of 74 bpm, blood pressure of 107/62 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and temperature of 36.6°C. The patient has a history of fever, which has responded to antibiotics. He also has anemia, renal insufficiency, diabetes mellitus, proptosis, ischemic cardiomyopathy, atrial fibrillation, gout, and sinusitis. He is currently receiving multiple medications and treatments for various conditions.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old woman with obesity hypoventilation, diastolic congestive heart failure, and respiratory failure who underwent tracheostomy. She experienced a deterioration overnight with nosebleed and hypoxemia. Her PEEP was increased to 22, and she showed left lung opacification on the chest X-ray. 

The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) from yesterday showed pH 7.39, PaCO2 59, and PaO2 105. Her vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 79 bpm, blood pressure of 114/70 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. She has atrial fibrillation (AF) as her heart rhythm.

The patient's hemodynamic monitoring shows a central venous pressure (CVP) of 30 mmHg, total input of 4,219 mL, total output of 2,510 mL, and fluid balance of 1,709 mL positive. She is receiving midazolam and fentanyl infusions, as well as various other medications such as ranitidine, heparin, and vancomycin.

Her physical examination reveals an overweight/obese appearance, crackles in both lung fields, and warm skin. Neurologic assessment is not available due to the patient's inability to stand or respond.

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old woman with obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS), diastolic congestive heart failure (CHF), respiratory failure, and a tracheostomy in place. She experienced a deterioration overnight with nosebleed and hypoxemia, leading to an increase in PEEP to 22. The patient's arterial blood gas (ABG) from yesterday showed a pH of 7.39, PaCO2 of 59 mmHg, and PaO2 of 105 mmHg.

The patient has a history of atrial fibrillation (AF) and is currently on multiple medications including antibiotics for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). She also has allergies to Capoten.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.9°F), heart rate of 79 bpm with a range of 69-85 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 114/70 mmHg to 141/83 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute with inspiration, and oxygen saturation of 97%. The patient's central venous pressure (CVP) is 30 mmHg, and fluid balance shows a total input of 4,219 mL and output of 2,510 mL since 12 AM.

The patient is receiving respiratory support through a tracheostomy tube with CPAP/PSV mode on the ventilator, with a tidal volume (Vt) of 522 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 22 cmH2O, fractional inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 60%, and peak inspiratory pressure (PIP) of 32 cmH2O. The patient's ABG shows a pH of 7.35, PaCO2 of 35 mmHg, and PaO2 of 105 mmHg.

The patient's physical examination reveals obesity, crackles in both lung fields, soft and non-tender abdomen, warm skin, and inability to stand due to muscle weakness. Neurologic examination is not assessed.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count (WBC) and platelet count (Plt), with slightly low hemoglobin (Hct), slightly elevated creatinine (Cr), and normal glucose levels. Other lab values are within normal range.

The patient's assessment and plan include acute on chronic respiratory failure due to OHS, CHF, and VAP. The plan involves weaning PEEP, continuing diuresis for CHF, and long-term antibiotic therapy for VAP. Sedation is to be weaned as tolerated, and anticoagulation should be held due to the patient's AF.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, further deterioration of heart function leading to cardiogenic shock, development of septicemia or other infections due to prolonged ICU stay and antibiotic therapy, and potential bleeding complications due to anticoagulation therapy.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese male with diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath and subsequent respiratory failure. The patient has had persistent respiratory failure, chronic fever, and mucous plugging or blood in the airways. The patient's respiratory status has improved with weaning of PEEP to 18 and stable oxygen saturation.

The patient is now febrile again, but cultures are negative, suggesting that the fever may be due to aspiration of blood, pneumonitis, and inflammation. The patient has completed an 11-day course of Zosyn and a 14-day course of Vancomycin for coag-negative Staph bacteremia on 10/24. He continues to be treated with IV Flagyl and PO Vancomycin for Clostridium difficile.

The patient's acute renal failure is unclear, with fluctuating renal insufficiency likely due to pre-renal causes. His blood sugars have been in the normal range.

The patient has ischemic cardiomyopathy with prior MI, now with cocaine on the toxin screen. He is allergic to ACE inhibitors and has diastolic dysfunction with an ejection fraction of 60-70%. He may not benefit from afterload reduction. The patient's atrial fibrillation is on metoprolol and coumadin as an outpatient, but

Summary:
The patient is a 70-inch tall individual with a weight not specified, admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of fever. The patient has a history of multiple medical conditions including obesity, diabetes mellitus type II, atrial fibrillation, heart failure (diastolic), renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, respiratory failure (acute and chronic), impaired skin integrity, and anxiety. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 101.5°F, blood pressure within normal range, heart rate between 72-91 bpm, respiratory rate of 14-33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation at 99%. The patient is currently receiving several medications including midazolam, fentanyl, vancomycin, metronidazole, piperacillin, and Lasix. The patient's laboratory results indicate an elevated white blood cell count, decreased hemoglobin levels, slightly elevated potassium levels, and abnormal kidney function tests.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Infection: The presence of fever and elevated white blood cell count may indicate an ongoing infection in the body. This could be due to a hospital-acquired infection or a worsening of the initial condition.
2. Respiratory Failure: The patient's history of respiratory failure (acute and chronic) and current ventilatory support suggest a potential risk for respiratory failure. Close monitoring of oxygenation and respiratory parameters is necessary.
3. Heart Failure: The patient's history of diastolic heart failure could lead to worsening cardiac output

   AF, cocaine-induced MI in the past who p/w acute
   SOB, with resultant respiratory failure who has had persistent
   respiratory failure and chronic fever.
   #1 Acute Respiratory Decompensation: Likely from aspiration of blood
   from nose bleeds.  Chronic respiratory failure from CHF, fluid
   overload, obesity also contributing.  PEEP now up to 22, O2 sat
   improved.
   - will wean PEEP as tolerated
   - continue Zosyn (started [**10-28**]) for VAP empiric coverage, today is day
   [**9-26**]
   - continue Vancomycin, (started [**10-24**]) coverage both VAP and staph
   bacteremia, today is day 13
   - continue diuresis as tolerated by electrolytes, creatinine
   - wean fentanyl and versed, on Haldol 5mg PO BID for agitation, monitor
   ECGs while on Haldol
   - add PRN Haldol to help with agitation from fentanyl weaning.
   .
   #2  Fever: Had been febrile for most of stay, was afebrile X 2 after
   Zosyn started.  Was febrile around peg placement.  Now afebrile X 4
   days.
   I    VAP- Started Zosyn on [**10-28**] for empiric coverage of VAP, given
   increasing secretions and fever.  [**Month (only) 60**] have had GNRs deep in lungs that
   did not appear on sputum.  Defervesed with addition of zosyn.  Now day
   10.  Re-assess endpoint as now has respiratory decompensation with
   likely aspiration of blood.
   ii.  Coag negative staph bacteremia- IV vancomycin, started [**10-24**], now
   day 13.  Covering VAP and bacteremia.
   iii.  Sinusitis- d/c
d Unasyn, ammoxicillin.  Most organisms should be
   covered with Vanco and Zosyn
   iv.  C. diff- Positive stool toxin.  Being treated with IV Flagyl (day
   15), PO vanco until 2 weeks after antibiotics d/c.
   - Continue to follow blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - Continue vancomycin IV (started [**10-24**], Day 13)  for bacteremia,
   switched dose to 1g q 24hours,
   - Continue IV Flagyl (started [**10-18**], Day 19), PO vancomycin (started
   [**10-18**] Day 19) for C. diff
   - Tylenol PRN
   - no vegetations seen on TTE but study is poor
 may consider TEE if
   has multiple other blood cultures positive
   - Continue screening cultures.
   #3 Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline; 1.2 on admission but has
   been in the 1.6
 2.0 range for the past year.  Was stable on
   admission, then worsened to 2.3.  Fluctuating renal insufficiency
   likely [**1-14**] pre-renal causes.  Now 1.6 and stable.  Patient did well
   with Lasix boluses.
   -          Continue to follow PM lytes.
   -          Lasix bolus as tolerated
   # DM: ISS with standing glargine. Will increase sliding scale today.
   # Normocytic Anemia:  Chronic issue. Per labs, unclear, probably iron
   deficiency+ anemia chronic disease.  Had bleeding episode, cauterized
   by ENT. Hct dropped 1 point yesterday, likely due to acute bleed.
   -heparin ggt off
 not an anticoagulation candidate due to repeat
   bleeds.
   -Continue to monitor HCT and bleeding.
   #Proptosis- Normal-high TSH, not c/w [**Doctor Last Name 598**].  Ddx includes infections
   (bacterial sinusitis, fungal invasion), infiltrative, neoplastic
   (lymphoma, leukemia).  CT imaging reassuring, with excess retro-orbital
   fat rather than lytic lesions or masses suspicious for tumor.  Per
   family is a long-standing issue.
   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin
   screen.  ACE allergic, so no ACE.  Pt has diastolic dysfunction with EF
   60-70%, so may not benefit from afterload reduction.  Though he has
   room to increase beta blockade, given infection, will hold off on
   increasing beta blockade.  ECHO showed mild pulmonary hypertension and
   tricuspid regurgitation.
   - Tolerating labetalol
   - Cont. to hold on [**Last Name (un) 239**] until patient more euvolemic
   # Atrial fibrillation: On Metoprolol and coumadin as an outpatient.
   Not anticoagulated [**1-14**] bleeding and Hct drop in hospital. CHADS score
   is 2 (CHF, DM).
   - not an anticoagulation candidate due to repeat bleeds.
   - Labetolol for rate control
   ..

   .

   post-pyloric tube placement by IR.

Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old morbidly obese male with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presented with acute shortness of breath and subsequent respiratory failure. He has been febrile for most of his stay and was initially treated with vancomycin for suspected staphylococcal bacteremia. He also received Zosyn (piperacillin-tazobactam) for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). His current medications include fentanyl, midazolam, lasix, and other ICU medications. 

The patient's physical examination reveals agitation, proptosis, tracheostomy with mild serosanguineous drainage, decreased breath sounds bilaterally, distended abdomen, and bilateral lower extremity edema. His vital signs include a temperature of 101.5°F, heart rate of 84 bpm, blood pressure of 113/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 18 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 99% on CPAP/PSV with PEEP at 20 cmH2O, FiO2 at 60%. His arterial blood gas shows pH 7.39, PaCO2 59 mmHg, HCO3- 117 mEq/L, SaO2 195, and Ve 7.5 L/min.

Laboratory results show a WBC count of 6

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 53-year-old man with respiratory failure and severe obesity. He has been febrile since yesterday and is currently being weaned off PEEP (positive end-expiratory pressure) on the ventilator. The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.5 degrees Celsius, heart rate of 75-91 beats per minute, blood pressure ranging from 114/71 to 142/87 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20-33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.

The patient has multiple comorbidities including chronic respiratory failure, obesity hypoventilation syndrome, acute on chronic systolic heart failure, diabetes mellitus type II, and atrial fibrillation. He is currently receiving several medications including fentanyl, midazolam, furosemide, heparin, allopurinol, albuterol, atrovent, nystatin, Zaroxolyn, MVI (multivitamin), labetalol, Zantac, vancomycin, Klonopin, and free H20.

The patient's laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, elevated creatinine, normal potassium levels, slightly elevated bicarbonate, elevated blood glucose levels, and abnormal liver function tests. Other lab results are within normal ranges.

The patient has been diagnosed with various conditions and the treatment plan includes continuing to wean PEEP

His vital signs show a temperature of 101.5°F, blood pressure ranging from 114/71 mmHg to 142/87 mmHg, heart rate of 75-91 bpm, respiratory rate of 20-33 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission except for fever and respiratory symptoms. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient has been on mechanical ventilation, increasing the risk of developing VAP. The presence of fever and worsening respiratory symptoms may indicate this complication.
2. Acute on chronic heart failure: The patient has a history of chronic heart failure, and his current symptoms could be due to an exacerbation of this condition. Close monitoring of fluid balance and cardiac function is necessary.
3. Clostridium difficile infection (CDI): The patient has a known CDI, which can lead to severe diarrhea and colitis. Continued treatment with vancomycin and

The patient is a 53-year-old man with a history of diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and cocaine-induced myocardial infarction. He presents with fluid overload, respiratory failure, and chronic fever following conservative bacteremia that was not responsive to vancomycin/piperacillin-tazobactam. The patient has been admitted to the ICU for further management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Decompensation: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may be due to congestive heart failure (CHF), fluid overload, and obesity. The acute decompensation is likely caused by a mucous plug. PEEP has been weaned to 18 cmH2O with oxygen saturation stable. It is planned to continue weaning PEEP as tolerated and increase FiO2 if necessary to maintain PEEP down. Antibiotics have been stopped as completed empiric course for ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Diuretics will be continued to improve respiratory status, and weaning of fentanyl and versed will be done while monitoring for agitation. Haloperidol will be used for agitation during fentanyl weaning.

2. Fever: The patient's fever has spiked through vancomycin/piperacillin-tazobactam and continues to be febrile today. The fever may be due to drug fever or sequestered sources of infection such as abscess, line infection, infective endocarditis,

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 53-year-old man with obesity, hypoventilation, diastolic congestive heart failure, and respiratory failure. He has been admitted to the ICU and is currently on mechanical ventilation. The patient has developed a fever and is showing signs of fluid overload. His blood pressure is within normal limits, but his heart rate and respiratory rate are slightly elevated. The patient's oxygen saturation is at 96%. He has an atrial fibrillation rhythm and a central venous pressure of 32 mmHg.

The patient has a history of several medical conditions, including hypertension, hyperlipidemia, diabetes, and chronic kidney disease. He is on multiple medications, including antihypertensives, lipid-lowering agents, antidiabetics, and anticoagulants.

Laboratory results indicate elevated levels of white blood cells, creatinine, blood urea nitrogen, and potassium. The patient also has low levels of albumin and hemoglobin. Imaging studies show evidence of pulmonary edema.

Assessment and Plan:
The patient's respiratory failure requires continued mechanical ventilation. The plan is to wean the patient off positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) gradually. The patient is also experiencing fluid overload, so lasix will be restarted to promote diuresis.

The patient's fevers are unclear in origin, and it has been decided to remove the left subclavian line due to the presence of a picture. Empiric treatment for Clostridioides difficile (C. diff) will be continued, and the patient will discontinue Flagyl while continuing with oral vancomycin.

Sedation weaning will continue, and the patient will be closely monitored for any complications.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a [age]-year-old male admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of multi-lumen stop on [date]. The patient has been experiencing fever, tachycardia, and hypotension. He was weaned off PEEP but desaturated to 88-89% with low tidal volumes after being laid flat for a chest X-ray. A central venous line (CVL) was pulled and the tip was sent for culture. The patient's condition is complicated by atrial fibrillation, acute respiratory failure (not ARDS), acute heart failure (CHF) on chronic, acute renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, impaired skin integrity, and chronic respiratory failure.

   Assessment and Plan
   A/P: This is a morbidly obese 53-year-old man with DMII, hypertension,
   AF, cocaine-induced MI in the past who p/w fluid overload, respiratory
   failure and chronic fever s/p CONS bacteremia not responsive to
   vancomycin/pip/tazo.
   #1 Acute Respiratory Decompensation: Acute likely [**1-14**] mucous plug.
   Chronic respiratory failure from CHF, fluid overload, obesity also
   contributing.  PEEP has been weaned to 18 with O2 sats stable.
   - will wean PEEP as tolerated, may increase FiO2 if needed to keep PEEP
   down.
   - Stopped Abx yesterday as completed empiric course for VAP
   - continue diuresis as tolerated by electrolytes, creatinine to improve
   respiratory status
   - Continue weaning fentanyl and versed, on Haldol 5mg PO BID for
   agitation, monitor ECGs while on Haldol
   - PRN Haldol to help with agitation from fentanyl weaning.
   .
   #2  Fever: Spiked through vanc/pip/tazo yesterday and continues febrile
   today although appears to be trending downward.   Considering length of
   Tx w/ Abx for VAP and CONS bacteremia continued spikes would likely
   represent either drug fever, sequestered source of infection (abscess,
   line, IE, clot), C. diff or noninfectious cause.  WBC trended down and
   remain down after stopping Abx.  Possibly infected central line site.
   - Pull central line send tip for culture
   - Consider TEE if continues febrile and/or repeat Bcx become positive.
   - Continue to follow blood, urine, sputum cultures
   - D/C IV Flagyl started [**10-18**]
   - Continue PO vancomycin started [**10-18**] and will end 2 weeks after other
   abxs stopped (stopped on [**11-7**]) which is [**2141-10-21**]
   - Tylenol PRN
   #3 Acute Renal failure:  Unclear baseline; 1.2 on admission but has
   been in the 1.6
 2.0 range for the past year.  Appears to fluctuate
   significantly, may need to allow Cr to increase in order to wean from
   vent.
   -          Continue to follow PM lytes while on Lasix drip.
   -          Lasix drip titrate to 130cc/hr UOP
   # DM: ISS with standing glargine. Blood sugars in normal range
   yesterday.
   # Ischemic Cardiomyopathy: With prior MI, now with +cocaine on toxin
   screen.  CVP 24 but high PEEP contributing.
   - Tolerating labetalol
   - Cont. to hold on [**Last Name (un) 239**] until patient more euvolemic
   # Atrial fibrillation: Rate well controlled.  Not anticoagulated [**1-14**]
   bleeding and Hct drop in hospital. CHADS score is 2 (CHF, DM).
   - not an anticoagulation candidate due to repeat bleeds.
   - Labetolol for rate control
   ..
   # Gout: Stable, continue Allopurinol
   .
   FEN: Hypervolemic extravascularly, continue diuresis as able; replete
   PRN, DM TF until patient cleared by speech/swallow; consider
   post-pyloric tube placement by IR.
   PPX: Heparin gtt, H2 blocker, bowel regimen.
   Access: PICC placed by IR.  CVL pulled today.
   Dispo:  screen for rehab facilities.
   CODE: FULL

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 53-year-old man with diabetes mellitus type II, hypertension, atrial fibrillation, and a history of cocaine-induced myocardial infarction.
- He presents with fluid overload, respiratory failure, and chronic fever secondary to community-acquired Staphylococcus aureus bacteremia.
- The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with CPAP/PSV mode, tracheostomy tube, PEEP of 18 cmH2O, FiO2 of 60%, and low tidal volumes.
- He has been weaned off sedation and has shown some improvement in oxygen saturation.
- Laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, creatinine levels, blood urea nitrogen (BUN), and C-reactive protein (CRP).
- The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal range, except for low potassium and magnesium.
- He has a history of gout and ischemic cardiomyopathy with previous myocardial infarction.
- Fever continues despite completing the antibiotic course, suggesting a possible drug fever or sequestered infection.
- Central venous line tip culture has been sent for analysis.
- The patient's acute renal failure is unclear, with fluctuating creatinine levels.
- He is also diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, not anticoagulated due to bleeding complications.
- The patient's diabetes is being managed with insulin glargine.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Acute Respiratory Decomp

The patient's current medical conditions include acute respiratory decompensation, fever, acute renal failure, and ischemic cardiomyopathy. He is also diagnosed with atrial fibrillation, gout, and hypervolemic extravascular fluid status.

The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 101.3°F, blood pressure ranging from 122/73 mmHg to 138/80 mmHg, heart rate of 80 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 28 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 93%.
